title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The tragic deaths on September 11, 2001 have forever changed the nation. Officers, emergency workers, and employees who responded to the attacks showed heroic actions. The response to the September 11 attacks involved heroic actions by officers, emergency workers, and government employees at the Pentagon, as well as passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 who prevented further casualties. It is important to honor the sacrifice of those who lost their lives to terrorism. The sacrifice of those who lost their lives to terrorism after the September 11 attacks should be recognized with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award a "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs for the medals. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93, and the Pentagon. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike silver and gold medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93, and the Pentagon. Before finalizing the design, consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties is required. Eligibility to receive the medal is specified. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike silver and gold medals to honor individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Eligibility for the medal is determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. The Secretary will strike duplicates of bronze medals to honor public safety, emergency, and other workers who responded to the 9/11 attacks, for display in their duty stations. Establishment of lists of recipients. The Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal under the Act, including victims from September 11, 2001. Consultation with specific offices will be done for making determinations. The Secretary will consult specific offices to establish lists of eligible individuals for a medal under the Act, including victims from September 11, 2001. The determinations made are final and not subject to judicial review. If any individual becomes eligible for a medal or a recipient becomes eligible for a duplicate medal, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
